questions.text: Sodium iodide supporter is present in all of the following except
questions.solution:
• The basal membrane of the thyroid cell has the specific ability to pump the iodide actively to the interior of the cell.
  • This pumping is achieved by the action of a sodium-iodide symporter(NIS) which cotransports one iodide ion along with two sodium ions across the basolateral (plasma) membrane into the cell.
  • The energy for transporting iodide against a concentration gradient comes from the Na+/k+ ATPase Pump. This type of transport is known as secondary active transport.
  • Option C and D: The sodium-iodine symporter (NIS) is also present in salivary gland, placenta, choroid plexus, mammary glands, gastric mucosa and ciliary body of eyes.

questions.text: A skeletal muscle of latent period, contraction period and relaxation period of 10s, 40s, and 50s respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency- Minimum frequency required for producing tetanus.

Key Takeaway:

The tetanizing frequency is determined by the contraction time, and for this skeletal muscle, it is 25 Hz.

questions.text: Which of the following waves corresponds to an Isovolumetric contraction in JVP
questions.solution:
C wave corresponds to an isovolumetric contraction in Jugular venous pressure (JVP) curve.

Waves seen in JVP:

'a' wave - Due to atrial contraction

'c' wave- Due to bulging of tricuspid valve ring into right atrium during ventricular contraction

'v' wave- Due to venous return when tricuspid valve is closed

'x' descent- Due to tricuspid valve ring back to original position

'y' descent- Due to opening of tricuspid valve

questions.text: Lesion in which lobe will lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination?
questions.solution:
In Bilateral parietal lesion, there is inability to copy an object or even a simple design which is called constructional apraxia. Apraxia means inability to perform organized movements in the absence of paralysis.

Other options:

Option A: Temporal lobe is divided into three regions: Superior temporal gyrus, inferior temporal gyrus and mediobasal portion of temporal lobe. Superior Temporal Gyrus consists of Brodmann's area 22, 41, and 42 which is primarily concerned with audition. Inferior Temporal Gyrus consists of Brodmann's area 20,

21, and 37 which is primarily concerned with vision. Mediobasal Portion of Temporal Lobe concerned with limbic functions and olfaction.

Option C: Occipital lobe is the area of the brain posterior to the parieto-occipital sulcus. It is mainly concerned with vision. It consists of areas 17, 18 and 19.

Option D: Frontal lobe is responsible for social behaviour, emotional response and personality. Lesions in it lead to anaemia, incontinence, impaired memory and antisocial behaviour.

questions.text: Right shift of oxygen- dissociation curve is seen in all except?
questions.solution:
• Increased HbF levels lead to a left shift in oxygen-dissociation curve.
  • The gamma chains of fetal Hb have less avidity for 2,3-DPG than beta chains of adult Hb.
  • Therefore, fetal Hb has higher oxygen affinity. This provides an advantage to the fetus to extract oxygen from maternal blood in the placenta.
  • Fetal Hb shifts the Oxy-Hb dissociation curve to the left.

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except?
questions.solution:
• All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except Serotonin.
  • Serotonin is responsible for inhibiting gastric acid secretion which is located on enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal mucosa and within the neurons of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Serotonin increases intestinal motility by acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

Other options:

Option B, C and D: The basic factors that stimulate gastric secretion are Acetylcholine, Gastrin, and Histamine.

Acetylcholine released by parasympathetic stimulation excites secretion of pepsinogen by peptic cells, hydrochloric acid by parietal cells and mucus by mucous cells.

In comparison, both gastrin and histamine strongly stimulate acid secretion by parietal cells but have little effect on the other cells.

questions.text: Pacinican corpuscle is stimulated by which of the following
questions.solution:
• Pacinian Corpuscles are mechanoreceptors located in the skin and deep tissues.
  • Pacinian corpuscle consists of a body composed of concentric layers (lamellae) much like an onion.
  • This is a rapidly adapting mechanoreceptor capable of receiving high frequency vibration.
  • Therefore, it senses vibration and fine touch. It also senses pressure sensation.

questions.text: A pateint came with hypoxemia and a normal arterial alveolar oxygen gradient. What can be the cause
questions.solution:
• Regional hypoventilation is the most common physiological factor for respiratory causes of hypoxemia(Reduced arterial PO2) and reflects a local ventilationperfusion imbalance resulting from a partially obstructed airway.
  • Also hypoventilation leads to inadequate ventilation and fails to remove Alveolar CO2 from the pulmonary capillary blood leading to hypercapnia.
  • So hypoventilation is the cause of both hypoxemia and hypercapnia.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance?
questions.solution:
Bronchus has the highest airway resistance.

  • The greatest amount of resistance to airflow occurs not in the tiny air passages of the terminal bronchioles but in some of the larger bronchioles and bronchi near the trachea.
  • The reason for this high resistance is that there are relatively few of these larger bronchi in comparison with the approximately 65,000 parallel terminal bronchioles, through each of which only a minute amount of air must pass.

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of PCT except?
questions.solution:
• All of the following ions like bicarbonate, glucose and amino acids have decreased concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule(PCT) except chloride which has highest concentration.
  • In the first half of the proximal tubule, sodium is reabsorbed by cotransport along with glucose, amino acids and other solutes. In the second half of the proximal tubule, little glucose and few amino acids remain to be reabsorbed.
  • Instead, sodium is now reabsorbed, mainly with chloride ions. The second half of the proximal tubule has a relatively high concentration of chloride (≈140 mEq/L) compared with the early proximal tubule (≈105 mEq/L) because when sodium is reabsorbed, it preferentially carries with it glucose, bicarbonate, and organic ions in the early proximal tubule, leaving behind a solution that has a higher concentration of chloride.
  • In the second half of the proximal tubule, the higher chloride concentration favors diffusion of this ion from the tubule lumen through the intercellular junctions into the renal interstitial fluid.

choices.text: End diastolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to the left without change in slope
Slope changes in EDV pressure curve

questions.text: What will happen to the pressure-volume curve when the contractility of the heart CHANGES?
questions.solution:
When contractility of the heart changes there will be slope changes in the ESV pressure curve.

End - systolic pressure volume relationship (ESPVR) refers to the maximum pressure developed by the ventricle at end systolic volume.

It is determined by the line intersecting the upper left corners of the loops of the pressure-volume curve and can be extended down to x-axis. The slope of this line is called ESRPV slope.

Other options:

Option A and C: End diastolic pressure volume relationship (EDPVR) gives information about compliance of the ventricle. The slope of the EDPVR curve increases with decrease in compliance and decreases with increase in compliance.

Option B: End - systolic pressure volume relationship (ESPVR) shifts to right with change in slope.
